Created in Blender, tidied up in Meshmixer then sliced in Cura.

Create a lithopane of any square image! Made this for use in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:238435. Print at smallest possible layer thickness and 100% infill for best quality. Make sure to invert the image during customization. Modified the original (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78719) to increase image resolution to max possible 150x150, and patch the customizer script to respect length/width/height dimensions.
Updated Dec 14, 2014, fixed compliance with overall dimensions parameter

Quick:
=====
Just click Customize Full:
===
  • Use GIMP (http://www.gimp.org/) with this plugin (https://gist.github.com/paulbovbel/414da6b29a8455c9f457) to generate a .dat file from your image.
  • Use OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/) with FullyParametrizedLithopane.scad to create an STL from the .dat file.

title: Box/Case for Arduino DUE and ethernet Shield with 4 I/O
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a demonstration box for Arduino with Ethernet shield.
With this device it is possible to simulate 4 inputs (4 LED two-color) and 4 outputs (4 switches).
If you install the POE (POE 802.3af) module, you can also power the module with an Ethernet cable.
I have designed this thing because I have to demonstrate how to integrate a diy domotic system (Arduino) with Asterisk for the state exam of 2017.
You can find my source code (which allows you to control Arduino with a web page) on my site.

It is very easy to build:
1, print 2 parts of the box
2, mount: Arduino - Ethernet shield - Poe module
3, install 4 led and 4 switches
4, connect led and Arduino swings with wire and panel
5, put Arduino inside the box and attach it with some hot glue
6, close the box and secure the cover with 4 screws
7, upload your code
8, show how it works !

This is only for Arduino DUE but if you want you can "remix it" for any other board ;)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a replacement door arch for cardboard doorways in HeroQuest.

It'll work with the original door bases in the game or with this design:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2299408

Note that this arch won't slide down into the very bottom of the slot in the 3D printed base, so the door will end up just a tiny bit taller than a standard door. Very slight difference.

I printed on a raft with supports.

Do you like to play games with dice? Do you find yourself unannoyed with QR codes? Then we have the dice for you! Until you memorize which pattern is which digit, this is guaranteed to require a cameraphone to decode what number you rolled! This is an update of the original Useless Dice model ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22986 ). Instead of using an image editing program to turn QR code pictures into 2D vectors to extrude (which had extremely bad results), this variant uses a Ruby script to generate the QR code pattern for each face, then writes out OpenSCAD files that build up each face from geometric primitives. For those interested in the messy details, the Ruby script is part of the source zip file.

If you have a single-color printer:
  • Print the core in a light color
  • Get some modeling clay (e.g. Fimo) in a dark color and jam it into the holes
  • Optionally, finish it with something like clear nail polish remover when dry
    • If you have a dualstruder printer:
  • Load both models, printing the core in a light color and the pips in a dark color

title: Banggood Realacc x210 FPV cam mount - carbon replacements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement part for the original carbon pieces, not as strong as carbon obviously but it holds up pretty well. Printed with PETG filament and I didn't break those until now.

There are 2 versions:
V1: Almost identical to the original piece. Only the FPV cam mounting holes a placed a little differently.

V2: The upper part of this piece is a little bit bigger/higher and also the hole for the standoff is beeing moved a little bit downwards to increase sturdiness, so that this part can be used with my action cam mount, which increases the stress on this parts, but still works very well. You need to put new holes into the actioncam mount to accomodate with this pieces. With the V1 pieces no modification is necessary but the pieces might not last very long.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2250512
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1766004
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1776940

When placing the standoff between the pieces, they have to be bent a little to the outside, which is meant to be (increases sturdiness).

Print with 0.2 or 0.19 layer height and 100% infill.

description.text: My favorite tool for removing parts from my bed is Emett's Razor Scraper: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19029, but I always had to look for it. Then I saw melodybliss' EZ-Snap Razorblade Cover, which uses magnets to snap on a cover, and that gave me the idea to create a holder that uses magnets and is bolted to my printer. There are two holes for M5 x 8 screws that bolt into T nuts in the extrusions. The magnets I used are 3/16" diameter by 3/16" long Neodymium magnets I purchased from http://www.kjmagnetics.com/. However, in addition to the STL designed for those magnets, I've made this part customizable so you can modify it to work with different magnets.

My husband came up with the idea of making it with my 3d printer, but doing it so that the posts are incorporated in the base part. This is the resulting print from that idea.
Since I have taken this picture I have revised the base part and it isn't as high but the posts are still the same height, will add a picture when it finishes to print.
The STL file that I have included is of the smaller base.

remixed_from.author: MacGyver
remixed_from.title: Sliced Human Skull with Mandible and Teeth

title: Skullcup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Once I printed the Scull bowl (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:460222) I wanted to mount the bowl and create a cup.

Then i found the spine (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:697686) and made them match with some interference in meshmixer. Added a base and couldn't be happier with the results!

The skull bowl and "spinebase" fits where the spine meets the skull and needs to be glued in place with the adhesive of your choice. Mine printed with PETG so CA glue worked great.

Added both the "spinebase" as a solid and as two solids in case you want to mess around or replace the base.

V1.1: Added one with support for the base when you print it on its back.

Printer:

Trinus

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I printed mine on its back, managed to avoid support inside the spinal column.
The amount of support is affected by the plastic you use.

The cup base might need extra support since it prints by it self in the beginning of the print and might cause failure it it comes loose. I printed with raft and the was ok but flimsy.

title: Simple Phone Stand (Large Phones and Phones with cases - works with all phones)

description.text:
A simple phone stand for wide phones and phones with cases.

**** IMPORTANT NOTES: ****

  • For optimal integrity the two parts were designed in such a way that they should be super-glued together.

  • To keep up with the small design I decided to to make the base overly large, please modify as you deem fit.

  • Due to the fact that I do not like the stand moving about each time I put my phone in and heavy and large phones might topple if placed with to much force I would advise you to find a place on your desk and stick it down with press stick or something alike.

  • Tolerances are high-ish so a good sanding might be necessary.

Notes:

Printed with PET-G
Wall thickness 1 layer

Slip this on a Sharpie Fine Point pen (aka: a "normal" Sharpie) to use it in a standard pen plotter. Note that regular Sharpies are too long to fit in a carousel-style pen holder. I'll look into updating this for mini-Sharpies eventually. This should be a snug friction fit, but tolerances are tight and printing it is tricky. There's only room for a single 0.4mm perimeter wall, and you'll need to print with support material. I printed with 0.2mm layers. Note that the long end goes towards the tip. Note: I made a parametric version of this adapter available here: http://openjscad.org/#https://gist.githubusercontent.com/beardicus/d668c0f6b96be53d16dc/raw/plotter-pen-adapter.jscad

Three tone steam whistle for kids of all ages! It blows very effectively providing the printing is tight with no tiny air gaps.

I printed mine with PLA with no scaffold. The overhang angles on the outside should be within most printers capabilities.

I suggest printing it on it's side, as on it's end, the pipe mouth area will not print properly. Too much flat overhang to print!

comments.text:
I was printing for my Grandson and after printing 103.77mm the print shifted to the side 2.55mm. This shift doesn't show up in my slicer or in the preview. I have printed a test column to see if it was the printer and it printed 150mm column fine, so I'm not sure what happened here.
Sliced with Simplify3d
comments.author: Tesla1963

comments.text: Hi Tesla1963. I must admit I printed mine on it's side. I can't find any fault in the mesh, so I am a bit lost with that. I know I used to have a lot of problems with prints jumping to one side with my K8200. However, having upped the voltage on the stepper motors slightly and getting a better power supply, I have had no further faults like this. Very strange!

title: Anet A6 Cable holder X wagon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple way to hold the cables for the x wagon :-)

One of the problems with the Anet A6 printer is that the cable
to the X wagon gets stuck with higher prints.
This is my simple solution for that :-)

I recommend to use metal spacers between the moving parts

later:
It came to my understanding that some people want to use a fan
so i made some extra parts to make this possible again

Now there are 3 possibilities:

1: no fan with the original setup
2: for my J-Hotend mod
3: for a fan with the original hotendsetup

also see pictures :-)
Blue PET-G one is the original setup without fan.
Black ABS one is the J-Hotend setup.
Silver ABS one is the original setup with fan

I also put the files per set up in a ZIP file to make it easier :-)

later:
I have made an additional part for this holder. See :https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2343666

PS: I know the word Cable is spelled wrong in the file names ;-) to long nights i Guess :-)
in my language it's "kabel" :-)

author: goyiyo75

title: Siemens Gigaset DA Series Telephones Wall Mounting Bracket

description.text:
Siemens Gigaset DA Series Telephones Wall Mounting Bracket

If you pretend to mount a Gigaset DA Series Telephone on a wall, you will have to use a screwdriver to lift out a small plastic bracket that is placed at the back of the unit and insert it into a slot in the handset cradle (the bracket must be placed in the cradle with the slanting edge facing forwards, as otherwise the handset will not be properly secured).

The problem is that the bracket doesn´t do a decent job, if you are not very precise when hanging the handset, it falls straight to the floor and eventually it will break. Also the small plastic piece is brittle, and it can break or get lost easily.

So I decided to design my own replacement and enlarge it by a couple of millimetres to improve its functionality.

I’m very satisfied with the result. Now my little daughters can use the telephone without fear.

==============================================================

Seguro para montaje vertical de teléfono Siemens Gigaset DA Series

Si deseas montar un teléfono de la serie Gigaset DA en una pared, tendrás que utilizar un destornillador para extraer un pequeño seguro de plástico que viene en la parte posterior de la unidad e insertarlo en una ranura de la base del teléfono (el seguro debe colocarse en la base con el borde inclinado orientado hacia adelante, ya que de lo contrario el auricular no quedará correctamente asegurado).

El problema es que el soporte no funciona muy bien, si no eres muy preciso al colgar el auricular, este se caerá directamente al suelo y acabará rompiéndose. Además el seguro es una pequeña y frágil pieza de plástico que puede romperse o perderse fácilmente.

Así que decidí diseñar mi propio reemplazo, alargándolo un par de milímetros para mejorar su funcionalidad.

Estoy muy satisfecho con el resultado. Ahora mis hijas pequeñas pueden usar el teléfono sin miedo.

Prusa

description.text:
Fully printable monster truck with four link suspension and four wheel drive and steering with three differentials. I wanted a monster truck that actually looks like a monster truck, and not a truggy with large wheels.

If you want to support my work you can use any of the Ebay or Banggood-links below before making purchases.

High performance with the new drive train and axle housings:
https://youtu.be/uLqwb3P9NfM

New van body:
https://youtu.be/2taKQ4_r750

NEWS 29.10.2017

I made a new van body for it. get it here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2655178
Or here:
https://cults3d.com/en/3d-model/various/80-s-van-body-for-the-ursa-monster-truck

19.10.2017

I added a new roll bar with mounts for 22 mm LED light buckets: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-high-power-headlight-system.html

12.10.2017

Added a new rollbar. Rollbar02.stl. Slightly easier to print and without lights.

07.10.2017

New side frames are up now. They allow side mounting of the batteries and are ideal for saddle packs for a lower CG to reduce the chance of rolling over. They can also be used with two shorty packs in parallel or even two full size packs if you want insane duration.

The file name for the new frame is Option - Frame01-sidemount.STL

05.10.2017

Added medium length suspension arms. These fall in between the existing short and long arms. The files are MidWB01 and 02. I like to use short length suspension in the front and medium length in the rear.

29.09.2017

There was an error in the central gearbox housing. The new diff didn't fit. I have changed the the flattest side of the gearbox housing slightly to make room for the upgraded differential.

I added a new set of steering links with ball links for adjustment and separate front and rear steering cross links. The front part is the same length as the old links. The rear link is 1 mm longer to give some toe in in the rear end. The file name is Steeringlink03

Also new is a set of servo savers for the recommended servos. Servosaver02 is for the Corona while 03 is for servos with a larger 21 teeth flange.

25.09.2017

I have uploaded new heavy duty axle housings. The file name is GB03. They use the same gears as GB02, but are printed in a different orientation and are braced. they are stronger in every way and I doubt they will ever break. The truck can finally be jumped without splitting the gearbox housings. :)

Attach the bottom half with M2x8 screws. Attach the top of the diff/input housing with M2x8 or M2x12 screws. Use an M2x8 or M2x12 screws to attach the ball on top.

25.09.2017

Added mirrors and windshield wipers for the body. A little bit of detail make s a big difference. I uploaded a photo of the car with them installed.

19.09.2017:
I added new versions of all the drive shafts and hubs with holes and slots for a 2mmx13mm pin to increase the load capability and wear resistance of the rive couplings. The files start with "option - pindrives". Make the pins from 2mm piano wire or brass tubing. Make them 13 mm long. I haven't tried them myself yet, but pin drive works great with PLA in another project car other car.

Updated the center diff to the same stronger gear type as the axle gearboxes. Also updated the locking adapters for the diffs to fit the new diff style. Difflock02.stl

There was an error with the printable tire. It was wider than the wheel. I have uploaded Wheel02.STL which fits the printed tires. I also added new narrow tires which fit the original Wheels01.stl and take less elastomer to print.

Added left and right tires for those that want to try printing tires. They are designed to fit the rims,and should be printable.

I have uploaded new front and rear diffs. They use stronger and coarser gears. I have run my PLA version hard for a few times with no problems so it's definitely stronger than before. The updated file is GB02-gears.stl

New abuse video with a new lighter printed body. I printed it with 2% infill which saved 130 g. The rear diff now has two ABS bevel gears, which seems to hold up really well. I suspect ABS will be a good, cheap material for bevel gears.
https://youtu.be/253u5Jxf34w

A couple of abuse-videos. It has nylon (Taulman 910) bevel gears in the diffs here. 35t motor and 2S 6Ah lipo:
https://youtu.be/Z1vkdOQ-rEY
https://youtu.be/YAPbxRjT4TU

21.05.2017
Removed the "gears01" file and replaced it with gear sets specific to the gearboxes they are for, to avoid confusion. The new gear files are called CGB-gears and GB02-gears

Changed the diff bevels slightly to improve gear mesh.

Fixed a slight error in GB02.

Added a servo saver and the associated links.

18.05.2017
Added a special version of the GB02 input called GB02-input-onepiece. It's a one piece part that requires that you pause the print between 22.2 mm and 23 mm and install both ball bearings before you continue the print. This creates a stronger part without gaps.
Also changed GB02 with a stronger version after I broke mine while jumping.

16.05.2017
I made small changes to GB02-input and mating bevel gears (in gears01). If they break, the new parts have deeper gear mesh for higher strength.

Made slight changes to the lower suspension arms to improve the strength of the screw holes of the clamps. Also slight changes to the outside of GB02 for strength around the bottom area. Still compatible with the previous version.

Added split frame sides for small printers. Frame01-split01.stl and Frame01-split02.stl

Most of the parts have been changed recently, and I consider the design finished, so If you have downloaded parts earlier I recommend you download them again to get the latest versions. The drive train and spindles have all been upgraded.

I added two optional short suspension kits for shortening the wheelbase. Use in the front, rear or both as desired. Each kit shortens the wheelbase by 20 mm.

I uploaded shaft02.STL over again because there was a problem with the parts. The 3x19 mm rod wouldn't fit between the couplings.

I added a new axle gearbox assembly which uses a new input shaft which doesn't require carbon rods or filing of flats on the rods. It's easier to make and is stronger. It is uploaded as GB02.STL and GB02-input.STL. I also updated Shaft02.STL with a more robust design. Note that GB01 is still available, but I recommend the new version. The new version replaces two of the 3x7x3 mm bearings per axle for the same 12x18x4mm bearings used everywhere else.

Here's a video showing the performance with a 35T motor and lipos. I don't recommend runnign a lower turn than this. The photo showing the motor and pinion is taken after all my testing is done. The pinin shows no sign of use. Looks new. If you want to run higher turns that's fine:
https://youtu.be/5AwsShacXhs

I added a photo of the truck with a cool lexan body from Banggood.com. Also attached is a photo of body post drilling dimensions, and a photo of the frame without body. Check out the new video with the lexan body.

News:
Changed "Frame03.STL" with an extra cross tube and also made small changed to "Spindle01.STL". Working on all the rive shafts now so new GB-housings, shafts and couplings will come up some time in the next few days.

News:
I uploaded some stronger spindles and live axle housings with stronger spindle lugs.

I made a body for it as well tonight. It is based on a Tokyo Marui Big Bear Datsun body, with modifications to better fit this truck. It has been widened to fit over the batteries and has special body posts. I attached photos both without and with paint.

I appreciate any donations for my hard work and releasing for free, but only if you enjoy the model. ;)

Indoor video:
https://youtu.be/QcU0pcj3w-Y

Outdoor video:
https://youtu.be/ImmNC9to3ko
https://youtu.be/ViAJE4_pjs8
https://youtu.be/re-wnSXd8GE

Torture test video with lexan body:
https://youtu.be/vNq2D7YLXdA

Assembly notes:
-Tighten the suspension arm clamps around the axle balls untill they allow some movement, but not too tight. The ball joint needs to be able to move with suspension travel.
-The axle gearbox halves may have some uglyness in the top where the 7mm bearing goes. Just remove any excess plastic threads and stuff the bearing in there. I've done it to many units without failure. I might improve this part of the design later on.
-Apply a small amount of grease to the inside of all drive joints so that the plastic knuckles don't melt from friction. I use cheap bicycle lithium grease. Any grease will do.
-Apply grease to all gears. This prevents melting and keeps them working for long. I made closed gearboxes so that they could be greased without contamination. I use cheap bicycle lithium grease. Any grease will do.
-The drive shafts and drive knuckles can be a little tight. They will bed in.
-The gears will bed in if they feel rough in the beginning. Most of the gears seem to be very strong and show no signs of overloading. The differential bevel gears can break with very rough use if they are made from PLA. I eventually printed them from Taulman 910 nylon, which survived my torture tests.
-The smallest differential gears need small shafts to hold them in place. Make these short pieces from 1,75mm filament. Super easy and plenty strong with five shafts on total per diff.
-Ball bearings can be a tight fit, depending on how accurate your printer prints. The holes are designed slightly oversize. Just press them in there or carefully hammer with something that ensures the force hits the outside race. :)
-The lower links flex when the car rolls. This is by design and works well.
-Some parts have alternative parts so that the builder can create variations and change the look of the truck.
-The screws all thread into the plastic parts without any metal nuts. It may be difficult to screw them in the first time.
-Though the hardware list calls for machine screws, similarly sized self tapping screws will work fine in most cases. The exception being where the part is supposed to pivot on the screw, like the spindles and suspension link hinges. The length can also be different than the recommended in many cases as the holes are usually much deeper than necessary.
-The rear steering servo needs to be reversed. If it can not be reversed in the radio the longer servo link can be used instead by connecting to the top servo arm instead of the bottom.
-The diff lock gear is not recommended for jumps and high speed bashing because it increases the load on the whole drive train.
-GB02 is recommended, but if you for some reason still want to use GB01, here are instructions: On GB01 The input shaft on the live axle is made from 3mm carbon fiber rod. File flats on each end to fit in the gear and shaft joint and . The flats don't have to be perfect. Also apply CA glue to the flats when assembling. The gear ratio between the input and wheels is 5:1.

Required hardware:

-Minimum 2 channel transmitter and receiver. This is the cheapest i can recommend:
https://www.banggood.com/Flysky-FS-GT2G-2_4GHz-Transmitter-With-Receiver-For-Car-And-Boat-p-1058725.html?p=HD240528697332015103
This is better because you can mix the steering in programming:
https://www.banggood.com/RadioLink-RC4GS-2_4G-4CH-Car-Controller-Transmitter-R4FG-G-Gyro-Inside-Receiver-for-RC-Car-Boat-4-p-1169456.html?p=HD240528697332015103

-540 or 380 motor and ESC. The prototype uses a 21t GoolRC brushed motor for overload testing. I recommend a minimum of 35T:
https://www.banggood.com/540-Motor-60A-ESC-Carbon-Brushed-Shaft-3_175mm-For-110-RC-Car-p-1187528.html?p=HD240528697332015103

The best ESC for it is the Hobbywing Quicrun 80A "Crawler Brushed" ESC which can be set up to run with reduced brake and reduced punch which extends the gear life considerably: https://www.banggood.com/Hobbywing-QuicRun-ESC-110-18-WP-Crawler-Brush-Brushed-80A-Electronic-Speed-Controller-p-1191275.html?p=HD240528697332015103

-Metal gear servos. Maximum 23mm body length. I use these: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/corona-ds-843mg-digital-high-torque-micro-servo-4-8kg-0-10sec-8-5g.html
These also work well, but are a little weaker:
https://www.banggood.com/EMAX-ES3302-Servo-Ultra-thin-Steering-Gear-Emax-Servo-p-940116.html?p=HD240528697332015103

-Six cell Sub-C ni-mh battery or 2S hard body lipo ( https://www.banggood.com/Giant-Power-11_1V-6000mAh-3S-65C-Lipo-Battery-T-Plug-Hardcase-Pack-p-1080404.html?p=HD240528697332015103), or saddle pack for the newest saddle frame (recommended).

-The springs are made from regular road bicycle tubes. Cut them as wide as you need to get the necessary tension. The butyl is very durable and won't rot. I used one of my old punctured tubes. I also use these rubber bands to hold the battery in place:
https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-Kenda-Bicycle-Inner-Tire-700c-18-or-23c-F-or-V-Inner-Tube-Road-Bike-Inner-Tyre-p-66651.html?p=HD240528697332015103

-In addition to the printable body you can use other bodies. I ordered this body which fits well: https://www.banggood.com/RC-Car-Spare-Parts-Shell-For-Traxxas-Grave-Digger-RC-110-RTR-Truck-p-961475.html?p=HD240528697332015103

-Four monster tires. I have not designed printable tires for it because it would take an absurd amount of rubber to make them and it's just so cheap for good tires. It probably takes less time to order and receive than it takes to print as well. :P I use the chevron version of the two in the following links:
https://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?icep_id=114&ipn=icep&toolid=20004&campid=5338226872&mpre=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.com%2Fitm%2F4Pcs-Set-Ruber-Tires-Rim-For-HSP-HPI-1-10-RC-Bigfoot-Monster-Racing-Car-12mm-Hex%2F311960463871
Or these tires:
https://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?icep_id=114&ipn=icep&toolid=20004&campid=5338226872&mpre=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ebay.com%2Fitm%2FOff-Road-Monster-Truck-D-132MM-W-72-Tyre-Tires-Fit-1-10-HSP-HPI-Redcat-RC-3003%2F262010734312%3Fhash%3Ditem3d010e86e8%3Ag%3AHIcAAOSwe~dTxkgf

-7 3mmx19mm carbon fiber, steel or brass shafts for the diffs and live axle gearboxes:
https://www.banggood.com/3x2x500mm-Stainless-Steel-Rod-Capillary-Tube-p-1058744.html?p=HD240528697332015103
2mm steel rod for the pin drive shafts and diff bevel gears:
https://www.banggood.com/22mm-250500mm-1_52mm-Thickness-304-Stainless-Steel-Round-Tube-Rod-p-1064909.html?p=HD240528697332015103
-4 to 8 3x7x3 ball bearings:
https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-683ZZ-3x7x3mm-Ball-Bearings-Deep-Groove-Double-Shielded-Miniature-Ball-Bearings-p-1148730.html?p=HD240528697332015103
-20 12x18x4 ball bearings. Search for "12x18x4 20pcs" on ebay for cheap bearings.
-44 M2x8 screws - differential gearbox assembly, upper four link clamp and steering link assembly. 24 of them for assembly of the two piece wheels.
-2 M2.5x22 screws - For mounting a 380 sie motor.
-22 M3x8 screws - Main frame assembly and steering spindle assembly.
-8 M3x12 screws - Lower suspension link and upper rubber band posts.
-6 M3x22 screws (M3x24 can also be used) - 540 Motor mount and lower rubber band posts.
-4 M4x20 screws - For the wheels.

Steeringlink01.STL - Steering links.
Steeringlink02.STL - Offset steering link for the servo saver.
Servosaver01.STL - Servo saver for installing onto the servo arm.
Bodypost01.STL - Shortest body post.
Bodypost02.STL - Body post.
Bodypost03.STL - Body post.
Bodypost04.STL - Body post.
Bodypost05.STL - Longest body post.
Bodypost05.STL - Body post for the rear of the Banggood Vampire Ghost Lexan body. Use file Body04.STL for the front posts for that body.

Suspension01.stl - Lower suspension links. Alternative 1. Choose the one you like.
Suspension02.stl - Lower suspension links. Alternative 2. Choose the one you like.
Suspension03.stl - Upper suspension links.
Suspension04.stl - Lower suspension bushing and rubber band flanges.

CGB-380.STL - Central gearbox and pinion for 380 size motors.
CGB-540.STL - Central gearbox and pinion for 540 size motors.
CGB-gears.STL - Central gearbox gears.

GB01.stl - Old version live axle gearbox housing.
GB01-input.stl - Input coupling and bevel gear for the old GB01 housing.
GB02.stl - New and improved version live axle gearbox housing.
GB02-gears.STL - GB02 gears.
GB02-input.stl - Input coupling and bevel gear for the new GB02 housing.
Difflock01.STL - Locking "gears" for the old style diff. Use if you want to lock the diff.
Difflock02.STL - Locking "gears" for the new stronger diffs.
Shaft01.STL - Live axle drive shafts
Shaft02.STL - Central drive shafts.
Spindle01.STL -Steering spindles.

Frame01.stl - Main frame sides.
Frame02.stl - Front and rear frame pieces. Alternative version 1.
Frame03.stl - Front and rear frame pieces. Alternative version 2.
Frame04.stl - Front and rear frame pieces. Alternative version 3.

Wheel01.stl - Monster truck wheel. Narrow type. Recommended for bought tires.
Wheel02.stl - Monster truck wheel. Wide type. Fits wide printed tires.
TireLeft.STL - Wide printable left tire. 83 mm width. Fits wide wheel.
TireRight.STL - Wide printable right tire. 83 mm width.Fits wide wheel.
TireLeft-narrow.STL - Narrow printable left tire. 73 mm width. Fits narrow wheel.
TireRight-narrow.STL - Narrow printable right tire. 73 mm width. Fits narrow wheel.

Body01.STL - The nose of the pickup body.
Body02.STL - The cabin of the pickup body.
Body03.STL - The bed of the pickup body.
Body04.STL - Posts with extra room for the thick printable body.

ShortWB01.STL - Suspension kit for shortening the wheelbase. option 1 arms.
ShortWB02.STL - Suspension kit for shortening the wheelbase. option 2 arms.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15-100%

Notes:

All parts are supposed to be printed in the orientation they open. No support should be necessary. The live axle gearboxes have cylindrical support built in, which is easy to break off after printing.

The prototype was made exclusively from PLA.

For the body I recommend printing with one perimeter only, and about 2% light infill (rectilinear or "fast" infills that don't cross over on every layer). The nose piece needs to have a plane to support the detail in the grille at 105 mm. The rear piece also needs a plane to support detail when it gets to 168.8 mm to support the inset pieces of the tail gate. I changed from 2% to 10% at these points, and added a few full layers to give support.

For longevity, the bevel gears in the axle differentials can be printed from a tougher material, like Taulman 910 nylon. I did this to mine after a severe braking and acceleration test session killed the PLA gears. The central differential is fine in PLA.

I printed just about everything with 30% infill. Wheels 15%. I recommend printing the spindles at 100%. Up the infill if you have problems.

Good layer adhesion is very important for many parts, so no skimping on the temperature.

comments.text: the axle shaft that clears the counter gear in the axle and has the little ridge to hold the bearing seems to be a weak point. the forces are so strong that the shaft is jamming into the bearing which wears away the little ridge. eventually the shaft cannot hold pressure against the diff bevel gears and then the transmission starts slipping. i didn't look into the clearances but a sleeve over the shaft that goes back to the diff bevel gear  and fits between the bearing and the bevel gear would support it much better under load and prevent the axle diff from slipping.
comments.author: Superclodbuster

comments.text: Gotcha. I had made it smaller earlier on as a mistake. I made the ridge bigger and reuploaded the pindrive axles. I also uploaded a small file with just the one axle for you. temp.stl

comments.text: Yes

I'm still in the process of putting my truck together but i got it running for the first time yesterday.
i'm working on the body right now and i noticed a slight problem with the Body02.stl, and body02-windows.
there are a few areas in the body where the model is too thin and you get holes when slicing the model.
on the body02 file the door panel gap lines at the bottom and bottom center cause holes in the slicer layers because they are too narrow.
I filled in a corrected model on my end thickening the bottom of the doors .5mm per side to stop the issue.
the body02 windows file has some more issues besides the same door gap issue it has some areas at the roof and top of the door frames being too thin and causing slicer issues. i noticed all this with .2mm layers.
https://s6.postimg.org/vduyi9hgh/door_holes.jpg
comments.author: Superclodbuster

comments.text: Use 0,4 mm extrusion width to print the body parts to save weight and avoid holes. The door lines will sltill have a couple of small gaps, but I left it like that because it's a door gap anyway, and hasn't given me any strength problems. The roof should not have any gaps when using 0,4 mm extrusion width.
comments.author: Superclodbuster

author: cun83

description.text: Can't finish that big can of energy drink?  Here is a lid that will keep it in style

You may need to sand/scrape the inner lip of this a little to get the fit just right so you don't crush an opened can when you try to put the lid on. Get the fit figured out on an unopened can first. This could be merged but I am having trouble with dual color merged prints so I cheated and printed the logo first and then while everything was still hot, I printed the lid right on top of the logo. Seems to work fine that way for this design. Don't move the objects unless you want to fiddle around getting them lined up again. Bed temp 110C, 0.2 layer thickness, no shells, 30% fill. I got the monster logo in CAD format here: http://grabcad.com/library/monster-logo Update: 5/14/12 I added a thumb tab and made locking lip a little smaller. Snaps on and off much easier now. Also added a version without the logo for simpler printing.

remixed_from.author: JKSniper
remixed_from.title: Tilted Adapter for Noctua UPGRADE Fan + 2x Fan Cover

title: Prusa i3 MK2/S Adaptor for 40mm Silent Fan

description.text:
Jure Korber made this really nice design for a 40mm Prusa fan adapter. To fit a 40mm fan on the Original Prusa i3, the fan has to bend outwards to avid collision with the left X axis motor mount. Jura made it tilt upwards as well, saving vertical space and better intake of cooling air.

I was looking for a minimal design, but still with a strong construction. Editing the original STL file is nearly impossible as it has a lots of curved surfaces. I decided to start all over with the fan specification and the twist... and ended up with a design very close to the original :-)

What has changed:

  • Smaller 40mm fan base and re-enforcement for screws.
  • Maximize air flow for cooling - No grill and adapter air outlet matches E3D air inlet.
  • Thicker base for better Prusa mount.
  • Fits Original Prusa i3 MK2 and MK2S.
  • Close to minimal solution.

For assembly you will need four M3 10mm screws for the 40mm fan and four M3 10 or 12mm screws. See photos.

I use the 40mm fan SILENT 4 as it is quiet and moves enough air for cooling (eBay USD $10). The best solution is still the fan from Noctura, but at a higher price tag. Both the 10mm and the 20mm Noctura fan will fit the adapter without collision.

Update: Added model with M3 threading for screws mounting the Fan.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

25% Rectlinear

Notes:

2 perimeters, 4 top 3 bottom layers.

The part on photos is printed in Prusa Orange EasyABS and vapor smoothed to give low air friction in duct. Part can also be printed in PLA or PETG.

Printing in ABS, I had to turn on part fan for the top 10-15mm to get best result (lowest setting).

comments.text: Newbie question. If I were to print this out of PLA, would there be potential for warping/melting since this is near the extruder?
comments.author: TheMadMan

comments.text:
I think it will work with PLA, but as you point out, it is close to the heater.
The fan will automatic run whenever the temperature is over 50C and cool the adapter and that should keep you on the safe side.
comments.author: TheMadMan

comments.text: Just to be sure, the Noctua cooler is the NF-A4x20-FLX right?
comments.author: thijxx

comments.text:
Both the 10mm (NF-A4x10-FLX) and the 20mm (NF-A4x20-FLX) Noctura fans will fit the adapter. Most standard 40x40mm fans can be used.
I use the Gelid Silent 4 as that was the one I had on hand - It is good but I would prefer the Noctura :-)
comments.author: thijxx

comments.text:
I ordered a Gelid 40 mm fan and its has a 4.5 ? 7.65 CFM is that right one? Also have you encountered any of the issues that gizmatron spoke of?
My last question is how did you wire it becasue it has 3 wires and the orriginal mk2 only has 2
comments.author: jordanarttm

comments.text:
This is the fan I uses. See my reply to gizmatron, until now I have no problems using the silent fan - no issues.
You only needs to use two of the three wires (Third wire is tachometer output). You can read about the wiring here: How PC Fans Work
As all wires is black, you need to look at the plug to find the two right ones. Pin 1 is ground (negative/black), pin 2 is positive (center pin) and pin 3 is unused and should not be connected.
comments.author: jordanarttm

comments.text: thanks
comments.author: Area51

comments.text: you need to be careful with using the silent fans like the gelid or the noctua.. there is a whole thread on this on the prusa forums, but the thing you need to look at in the fan specs is the STATIC pressure rating..ie the fans ability to push air around a blockage in it's airpath which is EXACTLY what the hotend heatsink represents. Original E3D fan is XYJ12B3010H, it has 4.08 CFM and 4.82 mmH2O static pressure. As a comparisom Noctua fan is NF-A4x10 FLX, it has 4.83 CFM (a bit more) but only 1.78 mmH2O static pressure, that is almost 3 times less. The gelid is a tiny but better than the noctua but not much.. I run a similar fan setup plus a completely redesigned layer cooling setup ( details on my page here) and the ONLY fan I could find in 40x40, pretty silent with near identical performance to the original 30x30 is the san ace 109P0412H901 which are a long way from cheap.. I bought two lightly used and so far zero issues. prusa thread here https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/improvements-f14/extruder-fan-specification--t1524-s70.html
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: There is a Noctua 40x20mm fan available now that has much better static pressure.  Has anyone tried that one?  It doesn't look like the extra 10mm of height will be an issue, can anyone confirm?
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: The height is no issue, it will fit and not collide. You need longer bolts for mount. Have not tried it.

comments.text: I think it will be no issue with the 10mm version. I bet thousands of people using this on a Prusa i3 mk2 and if there would be trouble like fire etc surely someone had posted a warning about that in the official forum.

comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: I think 7.33 is probably close enough to the original.. with the san ace I'm getting 6m50... I tested ALL the other duct designs and using this one https://grabcad.com/library/mk2_40mm_fan_duct-1 shaved a minute off the cool down time with no other changes to the fan etc.. I started with the noctua fan and the 9m+ cooldown time being close to double the original worried me as I leave my printer running overnight a lot unattended and it seemed a BIG difference to me.. if I have time I'll print your design and run the cool down test just for comparison. I like how compact it is.. not sure it'll fit with the dual ducted layer fan mod I did to my printer is the only issue, and as I can now see my nozzle as it prints thats one mod I'm keeping..

description.text:
Really useful jig for soldering 5.8ghz cloverleaf FPV antenna's.
All the components are held securely in place which makes it really easy to fine tune the position of the lobes and get everything soldered accurately.

1 - Insert your coax cable in from the bottom of the jig and tighten the three lower bolts to secure it firmly in place. You want to make sure it's nicely centered and the bolts aren't so tight that they damage the cable.
2 - Insert one end of your lobe underneath the washer and loosely tighten the bolt, just enough to hold it in place.
3 - Push the lobe inwards so that the bottom part of it is in contact with the outer part of the coax, then tilt it over to rest on the 45 degree support.
4 - Tighten the bolt up so the lobe will not get knocked out of place easily - not too tight though as it's only plastic.
5 - Bend the top of the lobe into position so that the top is in contact (or extremely close to) the inner part of the coax.
6 - Repeat for all the lobes and solder with a fine tipped soldering iron.
7 - Upload a photo to the makes and let me know if you liked it.

You will also need 6 x M3 hex bolts and 3 x M3 washers.

Designed for 0.8mm wire, but should also accommodate wire from 0.6 to 1.0mm in diameter.

I plan to add skew planar (4 lobe) jigs at a later date.

title: Leaflet Display (horizontal) cnc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When attending my first Maker Faire I had some leaflets to spread out the word on how cool things can be done with a payable cnc machine. They were design in landscape orientation and just put them on the table. All the time I thought it'd be cool to have some kind of holder or display. So, after getting back home I designed this leaflet display.

It was built from some 20 mm hardwood and a aluminum-polyethylene-compound material I got as scrap from a local sign maker. I used my desktop cnc-machine from Stepcraft and a spiral-toothed 3 mm flute for the wood and a 2 mm single-flute end-mill to cut the compound-material. After a little sanding I oiled the wood and put the pieces together without any further fixation.

Keep in mind that the stl-file is for viewing purpose only. It will not work if you print this on a fdm-printer.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

description.text:
This is a little marble maze for a kid.  It's a double-stack box with the maze on the center level, and a solid lower level to catch the marble when it falls through one of the holes.  The lower right has a wall cutout for retrieval.  
This is a pretty simple layout, but on the far right of the design files are various sizes of wall if you'd like to customize your own.  
We use an 11mm pachinko ball, which is heavy enough to have good inertia and makes a satisfying clack when falling through.  Resize the holes and passageways if your marble is different, or message me and for the cost of postage I'll send you a couple pachinko balls.  
I use "CorelLaser" on my chinese cutter, so I have to do different operations by hiding or showing layers.  The green (ENGRAVE) layer is just a quick marking, done here with 20% power and  50mm/s vector mode.  The black (CUT) layer is the cutout, done here with 8mm/s and 85% power (about 12mA on a 50W tube).  The grey (CORRAL) layer is ignored, and just used to keep the spare shapes handy.  
First rev had a misalignment on the 3-tab wall, seen as a small gap near the end of the start wall.  It should be fixed now, but let me know if you find any other issues.

description.text: A hanging bat I made for Halloween. It flaps it's wing when you pull the string.  Made from 1/8 in. plywood, I hung mine from a dowel but there's a hanger in the file.  Scale it up or down and populate your bat cave.

The points in the file mark where the holes should be drilled.  Keep them just small enough to fit a few loops of thread or fishing line through.  Once you cut out the pieces, sandwich the body between the two wings, line up the holes and clamp it with a clothes pin or whatever you have on hand.  Use a small dowel to help keep the loops big as you tie the wings and body together.  If you tie the loops too small, the wings won't flap.
Now cut three 24 in. lengths of string or fishing line.  Take each end of a piece of string and feed them up through a wing. Feed them up through one end of the hanger, wrap once around and feed them back down through the same hole and tie a big knot. If you kept the holes small the knot won't pull through the hole. Do the same thing once more for the second wing.  Now take the third string and feed both ends down through the center hole of the hanger, wrap it once around, back up through the hole and tie a final big knot.  The hole in the bottom of the body is for the weight to level out the wings and keep it stable. I hung a small 1/2 in. wooden bead from mine. Scale it up or down and tie your own weight underneath. The head and ears go where you think they do.

This ist my first little attempt to design a R2-D2.
I haven't created any 3D-object within the last two years so I'm not really concerned with it right now.
Particulary I have no clue of how to draw on the cylindric part, maybe I should check out some other CAD software.
This first sketch was done with Solid Edge v20. Any comments appreciated! The next step is now to build R2 in single parts that can be printed(regarding the problems with the overhangs too) and then glued together. I started with the dome, but I have to admit I got a little lazy in the end cause doing these spherical details is quite laborious in solid edge or I just didn't figure out how to do it right yet. It looks like the .stl-Dome got somehow mirrored from left to right, don't know why.

description.text: This is a replacement bridge for a Makerbot Cupcake to add a Mk5 Bridge compatible with a Makergear groovemount hot end.

1) Lasercut in 4mm Acrylic (should fit in the groove on your groovemount.
2) Assemble, some of the side parts will wobble when done in 4mm acrylic. This is fixed when you bolt it up. You may need to clean up the area for the groove mount. Slot your groovemount insulator in to the guide. push that through the bridge platform. Bolt the bridge to the extruder to platform, then assembled platform to rest of bridge.
3) Super glue the bottom pieces to hold it to the platform We had a gen3 extruder and wanted to use a Gen5 mount extruder. We made this by modifying the published files. We had to clean up some of the holes and make them slightly bigger as our laser cutter wasn't well tuned. For the extruder we used:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7129 The head was a Groovemount from Makergear, 36mm tube, modular heater core, .35mm nozzle. This will just clear the bottom of the platform when tightened and bolted in. If you have an issue with clearance you can grind down the mounting bolts that connect the toolhead bridge to the platform or modify the height of the platform mount in the SVG file before cutting. Some parts of the SVG are red. If your lasercutter software supports it, do those cuts first so that the large pieces do not fall until the end.

comments.text: I'd love to see photos when you are done! How long before we can call our Cupcakes retro/vintage 3D printers?
comments.author: Nova1313

comments.text: Cool beans! this will work finely for my cupcake restoration. ^_^

comments.text: Does this bridge warp over time due to heat radiation?

comments.text: I haven't noticed it warping. We've been running it since May of 2012. It's pretty close to the original cupcake design. Keep in mind that our cupcake is not enclosed, i yours is, you may have issues.

title: Stick-on pen holders for journals, diaries, and planners

description.text:
These are pen holders (for 1, 2, 3, or 4 pens at a time) that you can stick to the inside cover of your journal/diary/planner with adhesive tape. I use gaffer's tape because it is very sticky but it still peels off cleanly.

Because these pen holders don't have a bulky clip like most other designs, they don't interfere with the opening or closing of the book. If you stick them to the cover opposite your writing hand (e.g. to the front cover if you're right-handed), then this holder doesn't interfere with your handwriting either. And because it puts your pens along the edge of the book instead of along the face, you can still fit your book into a thin bag pocket.

Fits pens up to 12 mm in diameter.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount for small stepper motors like this. It is meant to attach a stepper to any flat surface such as a platform or metal piece.

Sorry for the blurry photos. I was taking pictures with my GoPro because my camera was charging
The piece takes a bit of force to get it on the shaft. If you want to take it off, it does take again, a bit of force, what worked for me was wiggling while I pulled.

Idea

I am making a 3D scanner with a Raspberry Pi and Pi Camera. The stepper rotates a platform. I needed a piece to connect the stepper motor to the plate, so I designed this. It is meant to be a quick easy print for projects that require small steppers.

author: junior_maker

print_settings.Notes:: When this happens the two Z-axis steppers can get slightly out of synch, upsetting the carefully done bed levelling, hence the need for these little chaps.

title: Get Ahead with 3D printing - Prusa Z-Axis Skull Pointer

description.text:
I had trouble being sure if both Z-axis steppers were in alignment.

So, I thought, I'll stick a little pointer on top of each z-axis screw so I can easily see if the two steppers are, ahem, in step.

I grabbed Bothacker's Skull off thingiverse (the STL one, not his real one), added a 5mm socket in Turbocad and... two watchful little skulls on top of each Z-axis. They simply screw on to the M5 rods.

Just get the z-alignment right, then make sure both heads are looking front and centre when Z-homed and bed levelled.

Hopefully, by their vigilance at all points of the compass they will also keep the three evil spirits of poor bed adhesion, combing and filament stripping at bay!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

none

Notes:

I have an odd problem with using Autodesk Print Studio. It uses a completely different approach to supports to Cura, and also allows you to easily slice bits of badly designed parts and print them as multiple items for gluing together.

The problem is that when it starts a print it goes down on the z-axis flat out, and can stall the steppers (perhaps I need to up the current a bit?) There's no dedicated setting for z-speed, so I can't slow it down without slowing down the whole print process.

When this happens the two Z-axis steppers can get slightly out of synch, upsetting the carefully done bed levelling, hence the need for these little chaps.

comments.text: It  is mainly at power on/off that they get out of synch. It does happen, not every time and the error can take some time to accumulate to a point it binds the axis. This is why many don't believe it is a real problem, that something else happen like the screw turned loose in the coupler.

title: Drive Shaft Bellows Retaining Ring Installation Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm apparently too cheap to buy the $30 tool from the local boat shop. This tool is meant to be used in a push-in (vs tap in) installation of the driveshaft bellows retaining ring.
there are three versions:

20mm solid (no cut outs, for folks who want to try the tap in method, I suppose)

20mm with cut outs and 10mm hole in the center (I have printed and tested this one)

22mm with cut outs and 10mm hole in the center (the 20mm version leaves a small gap at the small end of the ring)

Note This piece was an absolute PITA to remove from my BuildTak surface. I am printing on BT over glass over BT over aluminum, so I just removed the glass to a table. This made it easier to pry against without torquing my print bed. YMMV

Note #2 I am not responsible for any damage that you may do to yourself or your stern drive while using this tool. Use at your own risk!

StylusFlex was a Kickstarter project that I and over 1800 other backed some months ago. The stand itself is a simple flexible rod with a stylus tip in one end and a headphone socket in the other end.
The problem with the stand is that the rod turns freely inside the socket and therefore stand doesn't work properly as smartphone stand. This design failure has made many backers to throw the stand into garbage.
This repair tip I designed fixes the turning problem. Print the tip and secure it in its place with a drop of super glue. For iPhone 6 and other phones that are about 7-8 mm thick and the headphone socket is placed in the middle of phone's side.
Because rod's silicone is left there between repair tip and the rod itself, repair tip will turn a bit when in place allowing some adjustments to be made but the stand works as intended.

author: dpknuth

description.text:
Lamp shade #2 is a fully printable design lamp shade, consisting of one base-part and 32 segments.
The greatest thing about it is the color! When the light is turned off, the lamp shade looks nearly white (kind of pastel colors). But when turned on, the colors are rich and strong.
This great effect is the result of the colored layer printed in between the white layers.
It fits on e27 and e14 (adapter) sockets.
It was one of the first things i designed for 3D printing, when I received my Makerbot in 2013.
No I want to make the design available for everybody. I hope you like it, and I would love to see some of you make it!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

I got the best results when I print 3-5 of the segments together on the print plate.
The segments have a outer wall thickness of 1mm, so when you print with a 0.2mm solution, facing the plate with its outer side, it consists of 5 layers. The middle-layer is the coloured layer. With a single extruder printer you have to stop the print after the first two (white) layers and change to your chosen color and print one layer. After that, change back to white and let the printer finish the print.
The segments shall fit nice and self holding in the base (depending on your printer and settings). if you want to, you can glue them together.

Just print at 0.2 or lower if you want and you're ready.

Remember that at the beggining it will spin very little, and you may have to unblock the bearings if they are too tight by gently turning them.

Download Spinner V13 if you want to try it, it has many changes that should make it a better spinner

author: PYR

description.text:
This is a small library to detect the types of OpenSCAD variables/expressions. Publicly exposed functions are: isVector(x), isBoolean(x), isFloat(x), isDefiniteFloat(x) (float, but not NaN or infinity), isRange(x), isString(x) and typeOf(x).

The last of these returns a string describing the type: vector, boolean, float, range, string, undef, unknown.

Googling showed other solutions to the type detection problem, but I worked to make my solution as efficient as possible.

Update: More speed. In particular, I now avoid concat() and I also noticed that len() runs in O(1) time when applied to a vector but O(n) when applied to a string of length n, so I now avoid applying len() to strings, and as a result all the functions should now run in O(1) time.

Update: May 8, 2017: Optimized typeOf() by removing function calls and duplication of code between tests.

comments.text: I read " I also noticed that len() runs in O(1) time when applied to a vector but O(n) when applied to a string of length n, so I now avoid applying len() to strings, and as a result all the functions should now run in O(1) time."
comments.author: geoff_cohen

comments.text: Makes sense to me. OpenSCAD's len() scales well with vectors, but poorly with strings, so he avoids calling len() on strings
comments.author: geoff_cohen

comments.text: Is it the Big O notation that's unclear? https://www.interviewcake.com/article/java/big-o-notation-time-and-space-complexity
comments.author: geoff_cohen

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W Case w/Camera

description.text:
This is a remake of Dimwit-Dave's Raspberry Pi Zero WiFi Camera Case I really like how small a case he packed the Pi and camera into but, I have a Pi Zero W and a V2 Camera and the mounting holes for the camera or the board didn't line up correctly for me so I copied his awesome design and made it fit my Pi and Camera.

I'm only using this with MotionEyeOS so ~Case.stl just has a cut out for power... while ~Case 2.stl has cutout for the other two plugs.

Note - This will not work with the short 40mm camera cable.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

The Case & Cover. Required Hardware = (8) 2-56 x 1/4" screws, (4) 2-56" x 1/8" screws, and a 1/4-20 nut. Mount the camera with at least (2) of the 1/8" long 2-56 screws. (I just cut down and filed flat some 1/4" screws as thats all I could find at the hardware store.) Lay the board in the case so the ribbon cable lays as shown. Mount the board to the case with at least (2) of the 1/4" 2-56 screws and place the nut in the bottom space. Mount the cover with 4 of the 1/4" 2-56 screws. The case can now be hung with a screw using the slot in the rear of the cover or mounted to a tripod using the nut.

author: dpknuth

description.text:
Here is a twist on the spinner. Stack two spinners of any type (within reason/clearance) together on one shaft, add some caps, and you have something different.

Simple.

Shaft and caps are laid out at 8mm. Caps snap on nicely when I printed them. You may need to add a drop of glue depending on your printer.

The shaft MUST be a tight fit into the bearing or the spinners will wobble and contact each other, so you may need to scale up/down depending on printer and filament.

I use a Prusa MK2 and with .2 layers using BAM TACK filament, it is perftect.

I printed with no brim on the caps, and 2mm brim on the post.

I don't have any spinners, so I designed and printed 2 for the demo.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DghUpOcaJkg&feature=youtu.be
Fusion 360

title: Digital caliper holder for Flashforge Creator Pro bed leveling

description.text:
This tool is designed to hold digital caliper for bed leveling. I made it to avoid constant pain with bed leveling which involves eye-balling and playing with Feeler Gauges.

Intended use algorithm:
1) Level bed manually -- make sure you heated the bed first (temperature will temper readings). Make sure to heat your printer but not caliper.
2) Measure distance above each leveling knob
3) Next time you need to level a bed just use this tool to adjust knobs

Parts:

  • It assumes use of magnets to attach to rails and ensure there will be no fidgeting: "Magnets 6x3mm"
  • I used a caliper like this "Clockwise Tools DIGR-0105 Electronic Digital Indicator Gage Gauge Inch/Metric Conversion 0-1 Inch/25.4 mm with Back Lug Auto Off"

Notes:

When slicing -- I suggest to place/orient it like on 1st photo (on the edge). This way you minimize dimensional accuracy issues for inner circular features.
It's recommended to glue digital caliper to holder to make sure readings will be consistent.
It's designed in FreeCad and I made it parametric. By default sizes adjusted for Flashforge Creator Pro. But you can use "P" node to adjust sizes if you need it for other printer.

description.text:
Are you following along with TJ to build your FT Gremlin kit and wondering when he is going to release his Hyperion Camera mount? Well wait no further. This is simply my own interpretation of what he showed on camera but it came out great so I thought I'd share for anyone out there itching to use a setup similar to TJ's.

This is specific for TJ's Gremlin frame, but for all I know it will work in the others if the other frames have a similar layout to how the TJ designed his.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I couldn't wait any longer for TJ to release his design so I whipped this up this morning. My original print has 2.8mm diameter screw holes in the stand-offs. I don't have an M3 tap handy so I just ran a metal M3 screw all the way into all the holes to "tap" them for the nylon screws included with the FT Gremlin kit. This worked fine but was pretty tight so I created two more iterations (which I have not tried) at 2.9 and 3.0mm dia. holes in case they are more ideal.

This was printed at 0.15 resolution and I used supports. Most of the flat areas are only 1mm thick. The resulting mount is very light, very thin and also flexible. Be careful removing the supports and while tapping that you don't damage your mount!

The camera is tilted back at 10 deg. and I also included a cutout to allow the power wires to have a place to go without interference.
As printed Support material removed Camera snapped in place!
Fusion 360

comments.text: Any way you can beef up the back of the camera mount part by two or three layers?  It is way too thin.  Printed two up and one broke just trying to get it off the print bed.  The other is pretty flimsy and would not hold up in a crash.
comments.author: LitterBug

comments.text: I mean in fusion 360 how did you extrude the camera at the 10 degree angle? I'm self taught and don't know many of the more precise commands.
comments.author: Enterprise1949

comments.text: Oh totally different question.  For stuff like that I like to make a sketch on say the XZ or YZ plane (whatever runs down centerline of mount) and sketch the side view of the 10 deg tilt.  Then extrude it left and right to whatever width you need.  Then add more features or sketches later to make rest of clips or cutout for wires etc.
comments.author: Enterprise1949

comments.text: Thanks. I ended up making a big block then cutting it out.
comments.author: hackoholic

comments.text: If you look in the Thing details you will see I had to use supports.  The 10 degree angle is no problem at all but the top clips that hang out into space would fail miserably without supports.  Also note that depending on how strong your supports stick to the part, you have to be really careful taking them off because the whole thing is pretty fragile to begin with.

comments.text: Thank you for sharing the top!  I was going to print this in ninjaflex. I am currently using a generic gopro mount that I put on some foam and some moongel then zip tie down, but it moves a little much. Your design looks like it would be more stable and with some tuning, I would hopefully be able to get vibes out. I just worry about a velcro strap not being enough to hold the cam down and then blooop off goes a tiny cube into a bunch of grass somewhere. I just started with 3d printing so once I figure out design software, I may do something like yours that I can secure to the top plate as well but with an enclosed section for the gopro. But at this point, I'm messing up my pei sheet on the printer. I'll have to replace that before learning complex software. Thanks again!

Notes:

ergonomic holder for 12.9 inch iPad pro

Your back and neck are in danger

Feel tired and hurt when you keep reading web pages or watching videos on your iPad?That's why you can find so many iPad holders on Amazon. But they are not enough. Regular portable holders for iPad just release your neck for a little, and we need a real high holder for long time using.

This model

It is 160 x 80 x 284mm. You can print it on Makerbot Z18, Zortrax M300 or MakerThink Knight / Knight 2.

Compatibility

This version works well with 12.9 inch iPad pro. The slot to hold the iPad is 7.3mm wide, so it's OK for 12.9 inch iPad pro (6.9mm), but can't work with iPad.

About us

I design tools for daily works. MakerThink Knight 2 is the printer designed and produced by us. It's a 300x300x350mm FDM printer. X/Y axis is driven by servo + ball screw rods. So the real Typical Dimension Tolerance is ±0.05mm

I can't take much credit for this design because I mashed the two Remixed parts together to make this.
It clips on very nice and works well as a filament sensor and a filament guide also.

This works with the following optical end stop sensor.
http://hobbycomponents.com/home/580-optical-endstop-for-3d-printer-cnc-robotics

Edit
Added an extended sensor guide at request, I have not tested this version.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will need to use supports because of the way the main part has to be printed.

comments.author: modem7

comments.text: This filament guide is well fitted for the Monoprice clone of the i3, and assembles easily with a couple M3 hex nuts and bolts. I am not sure if the Monoprice printer has the same cabling location as the i3, but I did notice that you may loose up to the top 30mm of build volume due to the bottom of the clip. I found this out as I was raising the print head to clean it (unfortunately centered on the print bed). I had over in-put a fast move on the Z-axis, and had to watch it crunch the cables in slow motion (they usually pass just behind the metal frame edge).
comments.author: MakerFodder

comments.text: With the cables of the Monoprice being located on the front I don't think it would be possible to use this, it clears it with the i3 Plus because the cable is located further back.
comments.author: MakerFodder

comments.text: I'll have a look at this when I get back from holiday but I can't say I've ever had issues on the i3 Plus with losing space on the Z axis
comments.author: MakerFodder

title: E-sun Spool adapter for Reprap printer

description.text:
FR :

Slt à vous,
Cette fois une pièce d´adaptation (blanche sur la photo) pour l´imprimante 3D Microdelta Rework de chez Reprap, elle vous premettra de monter une bobine E-sun puisque la piece orginale ( rouge sur la photo ) ne passe pas, donc voici un model en 2 parties.

Pour le montage, pas plus simple, placer la partie 1 sur votre imprimante , puis installer votre roulement entre partie 1 et partie 2 puis utilisé une vis pour fixer le tout sur l´imprimante, et voilà . ;)

ENG :

a simple adapter piece for 3D Microdelta Rework printers which adapter piece can´t fit on E-sun spools ( red one on the picture ), so I made one made out of 2 pieces which are screw together on the printer ( white one the picture ), I let some place for your roller bearing, thas all ;)

title: Little Monster External Stepper Driver Box

description.text:
A box to house the external stepper driver boards to allow the use of TMC2100 drivers with the Tevo Little Monster.

This design utilizes the stock fan for stepper driver cooling and provides a way to securely mount the drivers to the Little Monster.

The board you see in the back is just a 20mm x 80mm generic perf board used to couple the power wires together.

Printer:

Tevo Little Monster

Supports:

15%

description.text:
Un petit cache pour cacher un trou laissé par un bouton dans la facade avant dans une Mercedes Benz 190E

PS : je ne sais pas si elle passe dans d´autre voiture :P

Ich habe diese Box erstellt, um die Sammelmünzenreihe Klimazonen der Erde der Bundesbank Deutschland auszustellen und schön zu beleiuchten, so dass die bunten Polymerringe wirken können.
Falls Ihr die Münzen auch sammelt, hoffe ich, dass euch die Box gefällt.
Der "deckel" der Box hat extra Löcher in die man die Münzen legen kann und sie somit von hinten beleuchtet werden, wenn man ein Leuchtmittel seiner Whal hinten in der Box montiert hat.
Die Box hat auf beiden Seiten Löcher, damit man das Kabel für das Licht hineinführen kann.

title: Wood style floor spooler for Ø 200mm x 65-80mm spools

description.text:
This spooler arises from a mistake.. yep!
When I installed a release 2.4 of Cura, and slicing main parts, I didn't pay attention about the message of auto scaling and I launched the printing process, so at the finish I discovered the surprise :)

I didn't give up and I have drawn the rest of the parts with the same scale and this spooler came out that I consider a remix of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219901

Print it with a wood PLA for a good finishing, the smell, the shape and mounting will feel you like a carpenter!
I used a wood PLA for visible parts, for bearing hubs I used a normal PLA with fine print definition. TPU filament for floor dots.

How I printed the parts:

SIDE: nozzle 0.8, layers 0.25, unfill 20%
CENTRAL: nozzle 0.6, layers 0.15, unfill 30%
FIXERS: (A and B): nozzle 0.4, layers 0.1, unfill 50%
HUBS: nozzle 0.25, layers 0.06, solid
DOTS: nozzle 0.25 layers 0.06, solid

HARDWARE

  • Bearing 619/6: 8pcs
  • Screw Phillips 3.5x19: 4pcs

author: DING_Done_IN_Garage

description.text: This is a Russian MIG-15 cut into 5 pcs for easy printing and gluing together. 300mm wingspan. On my Replicator 2x each wing is about 2.30 hrs at 0.2 layer height no supports, the mid section about 3 hrs, no suppot, tail section about 3.30 hrs no supports and nose section about 3.30 hrs with supports for center intake piece. I didnt use any rafts, you have to make sure you have good stick to pull this print off. All the prints were printed vertically, see pic.

Print pieces vertically, I used a 0.2mm layer height no supports except for nose piece because of intake piece. 15% infill but you can use less, 2 shells. Make sure you have good stick. Once all printed then glue together, I used epoxy resin. The pieces dont have a good key but there are surfaces that will give you a good indication. Todo list:
Make pieces key together better

comments.text: Nice model. But the wings look more like from a MiG-17

comments.text: This is a MiG-17 model, they must've confused the two names. The fuselage for the MiG-15 is shorter and fatter, and the wings were much shorter and a little less swept.

Found no mouthpiece that fits my flugelhorn, so I decided to design one.
Bore is 5mm, shaft ends at 9.2mm. Also fits to my cornett. Sound is really not bad as far as I can tell. I intend to use it outside when it is cold.
The rocket-wings are meant as support and need to be cut away.

Printer:

anet a8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50% triangel

Notes:

Support is included in the design to make a upright print possible.
Good build plate adhesion is mandatory, I use PLA on a glass plate @ 60°C and clean the plate before printing with alcohol. Hot end temp is 205°C.
I used a 5mm "brim" but this is probably not really necessary.
0.1mm gets a good shape with not too strong steps.
Printing took about 1h30.

This is an update to my former model of printable Buckminster Fuller Jitterbug construction (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckminster_Fuller).
To assemble it you will need 24 screws 3mmx11mm.
The model was designed in OnShape (a browser base CAD system). The project document is public and you are free to copy it and customise it in any way you want (https://cad.onshape.com/documents/9531448dfddd802cbd59f9ab)

Cable holder. very practical thing on your desk.
Print it and commend photo of print;)

This is a mug that has the lettering following the contour of the mug shape.

I have proved the link to the tinkercad file so that you can make changes. There are also a couple of Spiral Hart Shaped cups with no handles.

If you want to add a custom name to the mug it can be done. I am working on a tutorial that you can use to make those changes.

This is my second project to post, so give me some good feedback please.

If you want a copy of this project the link is below.

I designed this two object to make a place between the tube and the axis, without need to paste it on the printer enclosure.

You could use the open one if you don't want to remove the bowden
